newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK copyright ordinance beefs up anti-piracy effort.
newsitem.headline: HK copyright ordinance beefs up anti-piracy effort.

text.p: Hong Kong's newly enacted Copyright Ordinance provides stronger legislative tools to combat piracy, a government spokesman said on Thursday.
The ordinance was passed by the Legislative Council on Tuesday and will come into force on Friday.

To facilitate enforcement, the new ordinance reinforces provisions allowing courts to accept an affidavit as a basis of proof, and enables customs officers to seize and forfeit suspected pirated goods, he said.
Penalties for first offenders of copyright infringement were doubled to a maximum HK$50,000 and imprisonment of up to four years to increase the deterent effect, the spokesman added.

Parallel importation of copyright works will continue to be regulated, but criminal sanctions will only be enforced within the 18 months after the first publication or relase of the work anywhere in the world, the spokesman said.
A Patents Ordinance was also enacted to provide for the grant of independent patents in Hong Kong based on the registration and grant of a patent by Chinese, British or European patent offices.
Hong Kong will also have its own Designs Registry for the first time under a new Registered Designs Ordinance.
The spokesman also noted Hong Kong will formulate its own policies on intellectual property rights after the British colony's handover to China next week.
